qas.question: What was shown to be practically not possible during service trials?

answers.text: ranging and tracking the new high-speed targets

qas.question: Target area is relatively large at what range?
How was target lead watched at short range?
At long range what, in theory, could be used to set ranging calculations?
What small errors caused large errors in shell fall height and the time until exploding?

context: Service trials demonstrated another problem however: that <a0_0>ranging and tracking the new high-speed targets<a0_0/> was almost impossible. At <a1_0>short range<a1_0/>, the apparent target area is relatively large, the trajectory is flat and the time of flight is short, allowing to correct lead <a2_0>by watching the tracers<a2_0/>. At long range, the aircraft remains in firing range for a long time, so the necessary calculations can in theory be done by <a3_0>slide rules<a3_0/> - though, because <a4_0>small errors in distance<a4_0/> cause large errors in shell fall height and detonation time, exact ranging is crucial. For the ranges and speeds that the Bofors worked at, neither answer was good enough.
